clusters.title: Lachlan finally has control of Murdoch empire but deal is a win for sibling rivals
clusters.neutral_headline: Lachlan Murdoch Gains Control of Media Empire

items.title: Lachlan finally has control of Murdoch empire but deal is a win for sibling rivals
items.standfirst: Eldest son has the succession Rupert craved after agreeing a payout to his siblings far higher than previously offeredAs a keen rock climber, Lachlan Murdoch knows a thing or two about the importance of clinging on to perilous terrain. After the toughest ascent of his life – rising to the top of his father’s business empire – he has finally ensured that his place at its summit is assured.The deal Rupert Murdoch’s eldest son has struck with his oldest siblings Prudence, Elisabeth and James will mean they give up their shares in the family business, handing Lachlan the long-term control that he and his father craved. Continue reading...
items.content: Eldest son has the succession Rupert craved after agreeing a payout to his siblings far higher than previously offeredAs a keen rock climber, Lachlan Murdoch knows a thing or two about the importance of clinging on to perilous terrain. After the toughest ascent of his life – rising to the top of his father’s business empire – he has finally ensured that his place at its summit is assured.The deal Rupert Murdoch’s eldest son has struck with his oldest siblings Prudence, Elisabeth and James will mean they give up their shares in the family business, handing Lachlan the long-term control that he and his father craved. Continue reading...

items.title: Murdochs reach deal in succession battle over media empire
items.standfirst: Lachlan Murdoch will retain control of the conservative Fox and News Corp empire under the deal.
items.content: Lachlan Murdoch will retain control of the conservative Fox and News Corp empire under the deal.

items.title: Who Is Lachlan Murdoch, the Media Prince Who Would Be King
items.standfirst: A new deal gives him control of his family’s media empire, including Fox News, for probably decades to come.
items.content: A new deal gives him control of his family’s media empire, including Fox News, for probably decades to come.

items.title: Murdoch heirs settle dispute over control of the right-wing mogul's media empire
items.standfirst: Rupert Murdoch’s children reached a settlement in their legal battle over control of the media empire, his companies said Monday, cementing eldest son Lachlan’s leadership. The deal ends litigation from siblings who contested Murdoch’s push to install Lachlan, who shares his father’s right-wing political orientation, as successor.
items.content: Rupert Murdoch’s children reached a settlement in their legal battle over control of the media empire, his companies said Monday, cementing eldest son Lachlan’s leadership. The deal ends litigation from siblings who contested Murdoch’s push to install Lachlan, who shares his father’s right-wing political orientation, as successor.

items.title: Succession secured: Murdoch family reach deal over future of media empire
items.standfirst: The Murdoch family have reached a deal which will see Rupert Murdoch's son Lachlan cement control of the family media empire that includes Fox News and The Wall Street Journal.
items.content: The Murdoch family have reached a deal which will see Rupert Murdoch's son Lachlan cement control of the family media empire that includes Fox News and The Wall Street Journal.

items.title: Rupert Murdoch seals deal passing control of media empire to eldest son
items.standfirst: Legal settlement ensures Lachlan Murdoch will take control of sprawling media portfolio after 94-year-old mogul's death.
items.content: Legal settlement ensures Lachlan Murdoch will take control of sprawling media portfolio after 94-year-old mogul's death.

items.title: Murdoch family reaches deal to resolve succession fight over media empire
items.standfirst: Family announces Rupert Murdoch’s eldest son, Lachlan Murdoch, will secure control of businessThe succession battle at Rupert Murdoch’s media empire has ended.The family announced on Monday that Lachlan Murdoch, Murdoch’s eldest son, will secure control of the Murdochs’ sprawling media empire that includes Fox News, The Wall Street Journal and The Times in the UK, with his three oldest siblings receiving an estimated $1.1bn each for their shares in the business. Continue reading...
items.content: Family announces Rupert Murdoch’s eldest son, Lachlan Murdoch, will secure control of businessThe succession battle at Rupert Murdoch’s media empire has ended.The family announced on Monday that Lachlan Murdoch, Murdoch’s eldest son, will secure control of the Murdochs’ sprawling media empire that includes Fox News, The Wall Street Journal and The Times in the UK, with his three oldest siblings receiving an estimated $1.1bn each for their shares in the business. Continue reading...

items.title: Murdoch seals $3.3bn succession deal to hand empire to eldest son
items.standfirst: Lachlan takes control as three siblings receive $1.1bn each to settle long-running family feud
items.content: Lachlan takes control as three siblings receive $1.1bn each to settle long-running family feud

items.title: Rupert Murdoch buys out 3 of his children to seal fate of his media empire
items.standfirst: The owner of Fox News, the Wall Street Journal and dozens of other media properties has settled a legal fight with three of his own children over who would control his companies after his death.
items.content: The owner of Fox News, the Wall Street Journal and dozens of other media properties has settled a legal fight with three of his own children over who would control his companies after his death.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images)

ai_summary: Lachlan Murdoch secured control of the Murdoch family media empire through a deal.
Siblings will give up their shares in the family business as part of the agreement.
The deal ensures Lachlan's long-term control of Fox and News Corp.
Rupert Murdoch's children settled a dispute over control of the media empire.
The settlement ends litigation contesting Lachlan's succession as leader.

items.title: Nepal’s prime minister resigns after social media ban sparks deadly protests
items.standfirst: Thousands defy curfew as ‘Gen Z’ demonstrations against ban and political corruption continueNepal’s prime minister, KP Sharma Oli, has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontentment at political corruption and nepotism.At least 19 people were killed and hundreds were injured on Monday after protests against a ban on 26 prominent social media sites and corruption issues was met with deadly force by police. Continue reading...
items.content: Thousands defy curfew as ‘Gen Z’ demonstrations against ban and political corruption continueNepal’s prime minister, KP Sharma Oli, has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontentment at political corruption and nepotism.At least 19 people were killed and hundreds were injured on Monday after protests against a ban on 26 prominent social media sites and corruption issues was met with deadly force by police. Continue reading...

items.content: Protests in Nepal over a since-lifted ban on major social media platforms have left almost 20 people dead and now toppled the country's leader.

items.title: Protests in Nepal over social media ban turn deadly
items.standfirst: At least 19 people were killed as protests broke out over a government attempt to regulate social media that blocked some of the world’s largest platforms.
items.content: At least 19 people were killed as protests broke out over a government attempt to regulate social media that blocked some of the world’s largest platforms.

items.title: Nepal lifts social media ban after 19 killed in protests against corruption

items.content: Nepal's Communications and Information Technology Minister Prithvi Subba Gurung says the ban is 'withdrawn'.

items.title: At least 17 reportedly killed amid protest over Nepal social media ban
items.standfirst: Protesters demonstrating against Nepal's ban on many popular social media platforms clashed with police outside the parliament, reportedly leaving at least 17 people dead.
items.content: Protesters demonstrating against Nepal's ban on many popular social media platforms clashed with police outside the parliament, reportedly leaving at least 17 people dead.

items.title: At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
items.standfirst: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...
items.content: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...

items.title: Nepal Scraps Social-Media Ban After Clashes Kill 19 People
items.standfirst: Nepal’s government scrapped a days-old prohibition on social-media after the ban sparked deadly clashes between police and protesters that local media reported left 19 people dead and 347 injured.
items.content: Nepal’s government scrapped a days-old prohibition on social-media after the ban sparked deadly clashes between police and protesters that local media reported left 19 people dead and 347 injured.

ai_summary: Nepal's Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned after violent anti-corruption protests.
Protests were triggered by a ban on social media and government corruption.
At least 19 people died in protests against the social media ban.
Protesters set fire to homes of some top political leaders.
Kathmandu airport closed as a result of the protests.

clusters.title: 'Last Tango for the French government': Italy reacts to political chaos in France
clusters.neutral_headline: French Prime Minister Resigns After Confidence Vote

items.title: 'Last Tango for the French government': Italy reacts to political chaos in France
items.standfirst: France 24's correspondent in Rome Josephine McKenna takes a look at some of the reaction to the fall of the French government in a no-confidence vote in Italy, a country that itself is no stranger to seeing prime ministers come and go in quick succession.
items.content: France 24's correspondent in Rome Josephine McKenna takes a look at some of the reaction to the fall of the French government in a no-confidence vote in Italy, a country that itself is no stranger to seeing prime ministers come and go in quick succession.

items.title: France to get third PM in a year as Bayrou to resign after confidence vote
items.standfirst: Prime minister to hand in resignation after thousands of protesters gather to celebrate ousting and plan day of actionBayrou to resign – latest updatesThe French prime minister, François Bayrou, will hand in his resignation on Tuesday after losing a confidence vote that has plunged France into government collapse and political crisis.Emmanuel Macron has said he will appoint a new prime minister in the coming days, who would then have to form a new government. This will be the third French prime minister in a year, whose first task will be the major challenge of agreeing a budget among a divided parliament. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister to hand in resignation after thousands of protesters gather to celebrate ousting and plan day of actionBayrou to resign – latest updatesThe French prime minister, François Bayrou, will hand in his resignation on Tuesday after losing a confidence vote that has plunged France into government collapse and political crisis.Emmanuel Macron has said he will appoint a new prime minister in the coming days, who would then have to form a new government. This will be the third French prime minister in a year, whose first task will be the major challenge of agreeing a budget among a divided parliament. Continue reading...

items.title: Darmanin, Lecornu, Cazeneuve... Who is the running to be next French PM?
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron is seeking his fifth prime minister in less than two years after opposition parties united to kick out centre-right Prime Minister Francois Bayrou over his unpopular plans for budget tightening. France 24's international affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at who is in the running to replace the ousted PM.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron is seeking his fifth prime minister in less than two years after opposition parties united to kick out centre-right Prime Minister Francois Bayrou over his unpopular plans for budget tightening. France 24's international affairs editor Kethevane Gorjestani takes a look at who is in the running to replace the ousted PM.

items.title: Live: Macron on lookout for new PM as Bayrou set to hand in resignation
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron is on Tuesday expected to accept the resignation of his Prime Minister François Bayrou after the latter lost a confidence vote he had himself called over his austerity budget. Following the defeat in parliament Monday, Macron said he would name a new prime minister “in the next few days”. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron is on Tuesday expected to accept the resignation of his Prime Minister François Bayrou after the latter lost a confidence vote he had himself called over his austerity budget. Following the defeat in parliament Monday, Macron said he would name a new prime minister “in the next few days”. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

items.content: A Russian air strike on a village in eastern Ukraine's Donetsk region has killed multiple civilians, President Zelensky has said.

items.title: Russian strikes kill at least 20 people in eastern Ukraine, says Zelensky
items.standfirst: A Russian air strike on the eastern region of Donetsk has killed at least 20 people, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Tuesday. In a social media post, he wrote that an aerial bomb hit the village of Yarova and urged Ukrainian allies to respond to the attack, which he described as “brutally savage”.
items.content: A Russian air strike on the eastern region of Donetsk has killed at least 20 people, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Tuesday. In a social media post, he wrote that an aerial bomb hit the village of Yarova and urged Ukrainian allies to respond to the attack, which he described as “brutally savage”.

items.title: Greta Thunberg's Gaza flotilla hit by drone, organisers claim
items.standfirst: Global Sumud Flotilla says a fire was started but Tunisian authorities deny that a drone was involved.
items.content: Global Sumud Flotilla says a fire was started but Tunisian authorities deny that a drone was involved.

items.title: Officials deny boat in Gaza flotilla was struck by drone in Tunisian waters
items.standfirst: Tunisia denied accusations that a boat in a Gaza-bound flotilla was hit by a drone off its coast, saying the explosion came from inside the vessel. The Global Sumud Flotilla, an independent aid group, said that one of its main boats heading to the Gaza Strip had been struck by a drone in Tunisian waters.
items.content: Tunisia denied accusations that a boat in a Gaza-bound flotilla was hit by a drone off its coast, saying the explosion came from inside the vessel. The Global Sumud Flotilla, an independent aid group, said that one of its main boats heading to the Gaza Strip had been struck by a drone in Tunisian waters.

items.title: Global Sumud Flotilla reports drone attack on Gaza-bound ship in Tunisia
items.standfirst: Tunisian authorities find no evidence of a hostile act and say the fire originated inside the Family Boat.
items.content: Tunisian authorities find no evidence of a hostile act and say the fire originated inside the Family Boat.

items.title: Moment of suspected drone attack on Global Sumud Flotilla boat
items.standfirst: Activists from the Global Sumud Fotilla to Gaza say one of their boats was struck by a drone at a port in Tunisia.
items.content: Activists from the Global Sumud Fotilla to Gaza say one of their boats was struck by a drone at a port in Tunisia.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla says boat struck by drone in Tunisian waters, authorities deny claim
items.standfirst: Organisers of a Gaza-bound flotilla carrying aid and pro-Palestinian activists said late Monday one of their boats was struck by a suspected drone. Tunisian authorities denied detecting any UAV activity, saying “no drones” had been identified in the area. No casualties were reported.
items.content: Organisers of a Gaza-bound flotilla carrying aid and pro-Palestinian activists said late Monday one of their boats was struck by a suspected drone. Tunisian authorities denied detecting any UAV activity, saying “no drones” had been identified in the area. No casualties were reported.

ai_summary: A Gaza-bound flotilla reported a drone attack on one of its boats.
The incident occurred in Tunisian waters, according to the flotilla.
Tunisian authorities deny any drone activity in the area.
The fire originated inside the Family Boat, according to authorities.
No casualties were reported from the incident.

items.title: Apple’s Big iPhone 17 and Smartwatch Event: Six Things to Watch
Apple’s Big iPhone 17 and Smartwatch Event: Six Things to Watch
items.standfirst: Apple Inc. will hold its biggest product launch event of the year Tuesday, when the company is set to unveil the new iPhone 17 lineup, smartwatches and AirPods ahead of the holiday season.
items.content: Apple Inc. will hold its biggest product launch event of the year Tuesday, when the company is set to unveil the new iPhone 17 lineup, smartwatches and AirPods ahead of the holiday season.

items.title: Apple to debut new, thinner iPhone at ‘awe-dropping’ annual product event
items.standfirst: Company also planning to reveal Apple Watch series 11 and update to AirPods earbudsExpect Apple’s latest iPhone to look slimmer when it debuts on Tuesday. The company is slated to unveil its thinnest iPhone yet at its annual product showcase, promoted with the title “awe-dropping”. The event will take place at its Cupertino headquarters in the Steve Jobs Theater at 10am PT.Apple’s iPhone 17 lineup is expected to include standard, Pro, and Pro Max editions, along with a newcomer to the family, the iPhone Air. This newest edition of the iPhone is christened to be Apple’s lightest flagship phone to date in the lineage of its line of slim MacBook laptops, observers have predicted. Apple has not denied the reports of what’s to come. Continue reading...
items.content: Company also planning to reveal Apple Watch series 11 and update to AirPods earbudsExpect Apple’s latest iPhone to look slimmer when it debuts on Tuesday. The company is slated to unveil its thinnest iPhone yet at its annual product showcase, promoted with the title “awe-dropping”. The event will take place at its Cupertino headquarters in the Steve Jobs Theater at 10am PT.Apple’s iPhone 17 lineup is expected to include standard, Pro, and Pro Max editions, along with a newcomer to the family, the iPhone Air. This newest edition of the iPhone is christened to be Apple’s lightest flagship phone to date in the lineage of its line of slim MacBook laptops, observers have predicted. Apple has not denied the reports of what’s to come. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Apple will unveil the iPhone 17 lineup at its annual event.
The event is titled "awe-dropping" and will be held in Cupertino.
The iPhone 17 lineup is expected to include standard, Pro, and Pro Max editions.
Apple is also planning to reveal the Apple Watch series 11.
The company will also update its AirPods earbuds.

clusters.title: Slain New Zealand father kept bushland hideout with weapons, police say
clusters.neutral_headline: Fugitive Father Shot Dead by New Zealand Police

items.title: Slain New Zealand father kept bushland hideout with weapons, police say
items.standfirst: Tom Phillips was shot dead by police after nearly four years on the run with his three children.
items.content: Tom Phillips was shot dead by police after nearly four years on the run with his three children.

items.title: New photos show campsite where fugitive hid his children before being shot dead by police
items.standfirst: New photos show one of the makeshift camps where a father-of-three hid with his children before he was shot by police on Monday.
items.content: New photos show one of the makeshift camps where a father-of-three hid with his children before he was shot by police on Monday.

items.title: Images of Tom Phillips’ remote campsite revealed a day after fugitive father shot dead by New Zealand police
items.standfirst: After four years on the run with their father, Phillips’ three children have all been located and are ‘doing well under the circumstances’, say authoritiesPolice in New Zealand have released images and given details of the campsite where two of fugitive Tom Phillips’ children were found, after their father was shot and killed by police on Monday.Phillips had spent nearly four years hiding in the wilderness with his children. He was killed in an exchange of fire with police after reports of a burglary in the remote town of Piopio. A police officer is recovering in hospital after being shot in the head by Phillips with a high-powered rifle in the standoff. About 11 hours after Phillips was killed, two of his children were found safe and well at the campsite in Waitomo. It is understood the third child was with Phillips at the time of the shooting. Continue reading...
items.content: After four years on the run with their father, Phillips’ three children have all been located and are ‘doing well under the circumstances’, say authoritiesPolice in New Zealand have released images and given details of the campsite where two of fugitive Tom Phillips’ children were found, after their father was shot and killed by police on Monday.Phillips had spent nearly four years hiding in the wilderness with his children. He was killed in an exchange of fire with police after reports of a burglary in the remote town of Piopio. A police officer is recovering in hospital after being shot in the head by Phillips with a high-powered rifle in the standoff. About 11 hours after Phillips was killed, two of his children were found safe and well at the campsite in Waitomo. It is understood the third child was with Phillips at the time of the shooting. Continue reading...

items.title: Tom Phillips, fugitive father on run with children for nearly four years, shot dead by NZ police in exchange of fire
items.standfirst: Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities saidA fugitive father who had been hiding in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children for nearly four years has been shot dead by police investigating an armed burglary, police said on Monday.The whereabouts of Tom Phillips has attracted headlines around the world since just before Christmas 2021, when he fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a custody dispute with their mother. Continue reading...
items.content: Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities saidA fugitive father who had been hiding in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children for nearly four years has been shot dead by police investigating an armed burglary, police said on Monday.The whereabouts of Tom Phillips has attracted headlines around the world since just before Christmas 2021, when he fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a custody dispute with their mother. Continue reading...

items.title: Fugitive father shot dead by police – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed. Our full report is here: Tom Phillips shot dead after attempted burglary, NZ police confirmThe mayor of Waitomo, John Robertson, told the Guardian this morning’s events were the worst possible outcome for the community.“I’m shattered, to be honest, and there will be many in the community that are devastated that this was the outcome after three and a half, four years,” he said.So it’s just devastating news. Really the worst outcome we could have expected.No day that goes by that I don’t think about all four of them.It hurts every time I see photos of the children and of you, and see some of your stuff that is still here, thinking what could have been if you had not gone away. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Tom Phillips was shot dead by police after nearly four years on the run.

items.title: Ethiopia launches massive hydropower dam against bitter Egyptian opposition
items.standfirst: Ethiopia officially inaugurates Africa's largest hydroelectric dam on Tuesday, a project that will provide energy to millions of Ethiopians while deepening a rift with downstream Egypt that has unsettled the region.
items.content: Ethiopia officially inaugurates Africa's largest hydroelectric dam on Tuesday, a project that will provide energy to millions of Ethiopians while deepening a rift with downstream Egypt that has unsettled the region.

items.title: Ethiopia inaugurates GERD dam amid downstream tensions with Egypt, Sudan
items.standfirst: Ethiopia celebrates Africa's largest hydroelectric dam as Egypt and Sudan express fears over water security.
items.content: Ethiopia celebrates Africa's largest hydroelectric dam as Egypt and Sudan express fears over water security.

items.title: Ethiopia launches Africa’s largest hydropower dam, straining ties with Egypt
items.standfirst: Ethiopia inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam on Tuesday, a $5 billion project aimed at electrifying millions of homes. The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam has stoked years of tension with downstream Egypt, which fears reduced Nile flows, deepening regional rifts despite Addis Ababa’s assurances on equitable water sharing.
items.content: Ethiopia inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam on Tuesday, a $5 billion project aimed at electrifying millions of homes. The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam has stoked years of tension with downstream Egypt, which fears reduced Nile flows, deepening regional rifts despite Addis Ababa’s assurances on equitable water sharing.

ai_summary: Ethiopia inaugurated Africa's largest hydroelectric dam.
The dam is a $5 billion project.
The project will provide energy to millions of Ethiopians.
The dam has strained ties with Egypt.
Egypt fears reduced Nile flows.

items.title: 'Don't open your doors': Activists defiant as Trump launches ICE raids in Chicago
items.standfirst: The Trump administration on Monday launched a new immigration enforcement operation in Chicago, saying the latest federal crackdown in a US city would target the "worst of the worst criminals." But activists in the city remain defiant and say they will resist efforts by ICE to snatch people off the streets.

Activists say several people, whom they describe as “beloved community members”, were already arrested this weekend while on their way to work.

items.title: ICC to hear charges against fugitive Ugandan rebel chief Joseph Kony
items.standfirst: The International Criminal Court on Tuesday opened war crimes hearings in absentia against elusive Ugandian warlord Joseph Kony, whose Lord’s Resistance Army was responsible for the murder of some 100,000 people and the abduction of 60,000 children. Kony’s last-known appearance was in 2006 when he told a journalist he was "not a terrorist".
items.content: The International Criminal Court on Tuesday opened war crimes hearings in absentia against elusive Ugandian warlord Joseph Kony, whose Lord’s Resistance Army was responsible for the murder of some 100,000 people and the abduction of 60,000 children.
